description:
Recently I've had occasion to load in data that wasn't ordered like I wanted it
to be; for instance, (z, x, y).  This starts laying the groundwork for
modifying this on a generic basis.  At present, none of this is exposed to the
user; it's all internal.

Future PRs will allow coordinate handlers to be supplied to various loaders.

@jzuhone, your help with spec cube here would be great.

UPDATE 1: This is ready for review.  I have added a new "override" method for units on plots.  This is not my favorite way of doing it, but it will suffice until the next set of patches arrive.  Have checked spherical, cylindrical, polar.  For me, all tests pass.

UPDATE 2: I've added the ability to specify different axis ordering in the construction of an object via stream loaders.  For instance, I can now do:  `load_uniform_grid(..., geometry=('cartesian', ('x','y','z'))`.  This has not been documented yet as I am planning to do a bunch of doc passes once the APIs have all been settled, and I'm still uncertain how to manage the construction of a class to feed in.
title: Begin generic axis ordering

Something went wrong, you should checkout http://hub.yt:8080/job/yt_testsuite/132/

Do you think we should consider `ds.coordinates.x_axis` and `ds.coordinates.y_axis` part of the public API?  I've suggested manipulating these dictionaries on the mailing list when people ask about flipping plot orientations.
content.html: Do you think we should consider ds.coordinates.x_axis and ds.coordinates.y_axis part of the public API? I've suggested manipulating these dictionaries on the mailing list when people ask about flipping plot orientations.

content.raw:
Yup, I do. This change makes them instance instead of class level. I'm
going to make a more broadly sweeping change that will de-property-ize
them, but I want to do that in a future revision after some more answer
tests for plots are put in.
content.html: Yup, I do. This change makes them instance instead of class level. I'm going to make a more broadly sweeping change that will de-property-ize them, but I want to do that in a future revision after some more answer tests for plots are put in.

content.raw: Oops, missed that. Shame on me for not reading closely.
content.html: Oops, missed that. Shame on me for not reading closely.

content.raw:
No worries.  As I have read through this, a lot of ideas have been popping into my head.  Once this has been accepted (and I hope that's soon? :) I will do:

1) Add more tests for plotting of non-Cartesian coords
2) Allow different orderings to be specified through stream datasets
3) Remove polar coordinates and make them a slightly different ordering of Cylindrical.
4) (Longest term) Develop generic coordinate system.  This is ill-defined as of right now.

I've added these to the trello board I've been using: https://trello.com/c/u2S1BPfH/58-coordinate-system-refactor

This is ill-defined as of right now.

content.raw: Good catch!  I'm surprised this worked at all.
content.html: Good catch! I'm surprised this worked at all.

content.raw: This looks good. My only comment is that the ability to specify an ordering needs to be documented, but if that's coming in a future PR merging this in now is fine, particularly if some of the details are likely to change as you experiment with this.
content.html: This looks good. My only comment is that the ability to specify an ordering needs to be documented, but if that's coming in a future PR merging this in now is fine, particularly if some of the details are likely to change as you experiment with this.

content.raw: My hope was that -- since it's optional for now -- we could do that in a future PR, but I understand if you want it now.
content.html: My hope was that -- since it's optional for now -- we could do that in a future PR, but I understand if you want it now.

content.raw: I understand waiting until the api is settled, but I just don't want the docs to be forgotten about, as it's easy to do.
content.html: I understand waiting until the api is settled, but I just don't want the docs to be forgotten about, as it's easy to do.
